#â€‹585 â€” January 16, 2026

Read the WebÂ Version

Go Weekly

Go 1.26 Release Candidate 2 Released â€” Go 1.26 gets a little closer to its final release in a few weeks with a fresh release candidate including several security fixes in areas like archive/zip and Request.ParseForm. "Run it in dev! Run it in prod! File bugs!" says the Go team. The draft release notes remain a good way to get up to speed, as does Anton Zhiyanovâ€™s Go 1.26 interactiveÂ tour.

Junyang and Michael for the Go team

ğŸ’¡ Go 1.25.6 and Go 1.24.12 have also been released including the same security fixes asÂ 1.26rc2Â above.

Give Us Your Tired, Your Restless, Your Micromanaged, Yearning to Build Freely ğŸ—½ â€” Fluidstack is hiring across 50+ infrastructure and engineering roles across the country. If you want to drive deployments for frontier labs, experience real autonomy, and build the AI infrastructure our future will rely on, check out all our open positions.Â ğŸš€

Fluidstack sponsor

Are Atomic Operations Faster & Better Than a Mutex? It Depends â€” While atomic operations can be significantly faster than mutexes, that speed comes with trade-offs in complexity and correctness that often make mutexes the betterÂ choice.

Benjamin Cane

Writing Mutexes From Scratch in Go â€” Experimenting with other options to implement locks that are lower level than just relying on sync.Mutex.

Chris Rybicki

Stop Overthinking Struct Pointer and Value Semantics in Go â€” When creating a struct type, you can face decisions about whether to use value or pointer semantics. Rather than debating this case-by-case, why not establish aÂ convention?

Preslav Rachev

ğŸ“„ 'Losing' 1Â½ Million Lines of Go â€“ Tim looks at the complexity of adding up-to-date Unicode support to Quamina, a pure Go pattern matching library heâ€™s workingÂ on. Tim Bray

ğŸ“„ Porting MiniJinja to Go with an Agent â€“ MiniJinja is a Rust-powered Jinja2 templateÂ engine. Armin Ronacher

ğŸ“„ Finding and Fixing a 50,000 Goroutine Leak That Nearly Killed Production â€“ Serge spotted a hidden killer goroutine leak that had been growing for sixÂ weeks. Serge Skoredin

ğŸ“„ Racing with Disaster: Data Races in Go John Arundel

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

godump 1.9: A Pretty-Printer and Debug Dumper for Structs â€” Inspired by a similar feature in Laravel, this library lets you print structs, slices, maps, and more, in an easy to read fashion at the terminal. v1.9 adds optional field retraction, but other recent releases have added other niceties like diff support, HTML output, and a builder-style API for heavyÂ customization.

Chris Miles

Notify 1.5: Send Notifications to Various Messaging Services â€” Supports about thirty different services including Discord, AWS SES and SNS, Microsoft Teams, Slack, andÂ Telegram.

Niko KÃ¶ser

How Teams Add Leverage to Their Kubernetes Environments â€” If k8s isnâ€™t your product, why treat it like one? Learn what to own, what to outsource, and how to stay inÂ control.

Fairwinds sponsor

libgodc: A Go Runtime for the Sega Dreamcast â€” The Dreamcast, released in 1999, was Segaâ€™s last truly innovative console (with a whole 16MB of RAM and a 200MHz CPU!) and, amazingly, you can now build things for it with Go, complete with support for goroutines, channels, garbage collection, etc. The project even includes some games as examples, such as a Pong clone. Thereâ€™s extensive documentation too.

Panagiotis Georgiadis et al.

go-astiav: ffmpeg Bindings for Go â€” The goal is to provide a more idiomatically Go API for FFmpegâ€™s various multimedia features. Now supports FFmpegÂ 8.

Quentin Renard

parse-dmarc: A Lightweight, Self-hosted DMARC Report Parser â€” DMARC is an email authentication standard used, in part, to prevent email address spoofing. There are numerous services that can collect and collate DMARC reports for you, but this gives you a single binary solution complete with a Vue-poweredÂ frontend.

Meysam

  • Chroma 2.22 â€“ Pygments-inspired general purpose syntax highlighter in pureÂ Go. There's an online playground if you want to give it aÂ spinÂ (above).

  • Warp v1.4 â€“ S3 benchmarking tool supporting concurrent operations, multiple hosts, and distributed testing.

  • AWS Lambda for Go v1.52.0 â€“ Libraries, samples and tools that help Go developers build AWS Lambda functions.

  • Terratest v0.55.0 â€“ Library for writing automated tests for infrastructureÂ code.

  • River 0.30 â€“ Fast & reliable Postgres-powered background jobsÂ system.

  • hcloud v2.35.0 â€“ Official Go library for the Hetzner CloudÂ API.

  • quic-go 0.59 â€“ Pure Go QUICÂ implementation.

  • Air 1.64 â€“ Live reload for GoÂ apps.

ğŸ“¢Â  Elsewhere in the ecosystem

Some other interesting stories in the broader landscape:

  • There's a surprisingly large ecosystem of retro Windows users and developers, and both go-legacy-win7 and go-legacy-winxp make it possible to compile Go programs for Windows 7 and Windows XPÂ respectively.

  • ğŸ¤– Even Linus Torvalds is 'vibe coding' now. He's been using Google's Antigravity tool to create some digital soundÂ effects.

  • goscript is a curious, experimental tool that translates Go code to TypeScript at the AST level so you can share algorithms and business logic between your Go backend and TypeScriptÂ frontend.

  • ğŸ“˜ The Concise TypeScript Book is a short, focused TypeScript guide that's open and free toÂ read.

  • Artem Golubin suggests you probably don't need Oh My Zsh.

item.description:
ã€

#â€‹584 â€” January 9, 2026

Read the WebÂ Version

ğŸ‘‹ A quick reminder before we get into the first issue of the year â€” Go Weekly is now sent every Friday (starting today!) as part of a reshuffle for many of ourÂ newsletters.
__
Your editor, Peter Cooper

Go Weekly

The Go 1.26 Interactive Tour â€” Weâ€™re now just a month away from the final release of Go 1.26 and Anton is back with another of his epic roundups of whatâ€™s new, featuring a huge array of live examples (powered by codapi.) If it helps you get even more excited, Anton concludes: â€œGo 1.26 is incredibly big â€” itâ€™s the largest release Iâ€™ve everÂ seenâ€.

Anton Zhiyanov

ğŸ’¡ Anton produced a similar interactive tour for Go 1.25Â too.

Go Errors? Fix â€˜Em Fast for Free with Honeybadger â€” If you support web apps in production, you need intelligent logging with error alerts and de-duping. Honeybadger filters out the noise and transforms your Go logs into contextual issues so you can find and fix errors fast. Get your FREE accountÂ â†’

Honeybadger sponsor

The Most Popular Go Dependency Is... â€” â€¦not too surprising, once you see it. However, the process Thibaut went through to learn that fact is fascinating. Read on to discover the top 10 dependencies and learn how he did it. Weâ€™ve resisted the temptation to post a spoiler, just this once, as itâ€™s a neatÂ post.

Thibaut Rousseau

IN BRIEF:

  • â–¶ï¸ A 5-minute clip of Ken Thompson talking about his role in the creation of Go. It's from â–¶ï¸ this 4-hour interview covering the entirety of Ken'sÂ career.

  • One of Ruby's most prolific developers, Marco Roth, has been working on porting Charm's popular Go TUI libraries to Ruby (technically, some are bindings to the GoÂ libraries).

Turning a Go Program into a Script with One Magic Line â€” A cute way to turn a regular Go program into a script you can run using something like ./script.go. A fun shell trick that certainly surprised me and which I adapted to also work withÂ C.

Lorentz App

go.sum is Not a Lockfile â€” While most languages have a manifest and a lockfile, Go takes a different approach with a requirements file (go.mod) and a checksum database cache file (go.sum). Some assume that the latter can be used to analyze dependency graphs, but itÂ canâ€™t.

Filippo Valsorda

ğŸ“„ Two Concurrency Patterns Which Avoid Goroutine Leaks Nick Ripley

ğŸ“„ Does Go Actually Implement the IEEE-754 Floating Point Spec? â€“ Spoiler: Yes, but it doesnâ€™t mean your math will beÂ portable. Nick Tobey

ğŸ“„ Using eBPF to Load-Balance Traffic Across UDP Sockets with Go Vincent Bernat

ğŸ“„ A Practical Guide to Building a Parser in Go Tomasz GÄ…gor

ğŸ“„ Go 1.26's Modernized go fix Command Anton Zhiyanov

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

  • ğŸ¤– Crush 0.31 â€“ Charm's Go-powered terminal-based AI coding assistant. Now supports "skills" a la ClaudeÂ Code.

  • â˜ï¸ SIPGO v1.0 â€“ Library for writing fast SIP (Session Initiation Protocol)Â services.

  • GoFr 1.52 â€“ The opinionated microservice development framework adds Redis PubSubÂ support.

  • Katana 1.4 â€“ Next-gen crawling and spideringÂ framework. v1.4 adds headless modeÂ support.

  • k6 1.5 â€“ Modern Go + JavaScript-powered load testing tool.Â (Homepage)

  • Listmonk 6.0 â€“ Self hosted email newsletterÂ system. (Homepage)

  • Echo 4.15 â€“ High performance, minimalist Go webÂ framework.

  • GoBGP 4.2 â€“ BGP implementation inÂ Go.

ğŸ“º The Top Go Weekly Videos of 2025

In the final issue of 2025, we reflected on the top ten articles of the year, based on reader engagement, but as I was looking at the videos, I noticed just how many gems there were there too.

Note: These are all links to YouTube videos, though the final two items have writtenÂ alternatives.

1.Â Developing a Terminal App in Go with Bubble Tea â€” A well produced 50-minute screencast walking through the creation of a practical note-taking command line tool using Go and Charmâ€™s Bubble Tea and Lip Gloss for structure, views, andÂ styling.

Package Main

2.Â The Creator of Ghostty on Zig Over Go â€” We only included this controversial video as a mini item, but it was still very popular! Mitchell Hashimoto (of HashiCorp fame) has spent the last couple of years building Ghostty, a fast new terminal emulator, in Zig. But why notÂ Go?

ThePrimeTime

3.Â Reverse Engineering Doesn't Have to Be Hard â€” An introductory look at reverse engineering a piece of Go-powered malware. Itâ€™s not aimed at Go developers and no Go coding is involved, but if you havenâ€™t done any reverse engineering before, youâ€™ll pick up someÂ techniques.

John Hammond

4.Â Advancing Go Garbage Collection with Green Tea â€” Michael of the Go team deftly explains how Goâ€™s garbage collection works and how the new so-called â€˜green teaâ€™ approach will make things better by default in the imminent Go 1.26 (and already available as an option in Go 1.25).

Michael Knyszek

ğŸ’¡ The Go team also published a blog post about Green Tea back in October, if you'd rather read aboutÂ it.

5.Â What is sync.Pool and How to Use It Properly â€” When you've got temporary objects that don't need to outlive the functions using them, sync.Pool can help you reuse those objects across calls and reduce GC churn. Phuong's article about sync.Pool was also one of our most popular articles of 2024, if you'd prefer to read about it.

Phuong Le

item.title: ã€Go 1.26 RC1, and the top links of 2025ã€‘Go 1.26 RC1ï¼Œä»¥åŠ 2025 å¹´çš„é¡¶çº§é“¾æ¥
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹583 â€” December 17, 2025

Read the WebÂ Version

ğŸ„ It's the last issue of 2025, so we're looking back over some of the big stories and links of the year. Also, Go Weekly will be moving to Fridays in January 2026, as part of a reshuffle for many of ourÂ newsletters.
__
Your editor, Peter Cooper

Go Weekly

Go 1.26 Release Candidate 1 Released â€” No official blog post yet, but a note that Go 1.26 RC1 has landed containing everything the final 1.26 release in February 2026 should have, barring any bugs fixed during the RCÂ process.

Michael and David (The Go Team)

The Draft Go 1.26 Release Notes â€” The in-progress, draft release notes are worth another review this week given the feature freeze, especially if you're giving RC1 (above) a spin.

The Go Team

MACROSCOPE - 86% Bug Detection Rate for Go â€” In our benchmark of AI code review tools, Macroscope detected 86% of Go bugsâ€”the highest rate on the market. Ship fewer bugs, merge faster. Use discount code MACROGO to get 50% off your first 2Â months.

Macroscope sponsor

IN BRIEF:

  • TinyGo v0.40.0 has been released with some notable GC performance improvements, LLVM 20 support, and support for yet moreÂ devices.

  • ğŸ¤– Charm's Go-powered agentic development tool, Crush, has had a stream of updates in the past week, adding features like to-dos, GPT 5.2 support, and projectÂ tracking.

  • ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸ GopherCon is back in 2026, subject to change but tentatively taking place in Seattle next August 6 â€“ hat tip to this episode of Cup o' Go for the reveal. We'll announce the CFP once it goes live.

  • ğŸ“º Talking of GopherCon, numerous videos of talks from GopherCon 2025 have begun rolling out on YouTube this week. We'll feature some in the new year, but there are already 14 talks toÂ enjoy.

  • ğŸ‡§ğŸ‡ª The schedule for the Go track at FOSDEM 26, taking place in Brussels next February 1 has been unveiled.

ğŸ† The Top Go Weekly Items of 2025

1.Â JSON Evolution in Go: From V1 to V2 â€” A good look into the practicalities of using the JSON v2 package which landed in Go 1.25 this August with new field tags, updated marshal defaults, streaming APIs, and otherÂ niceties.

Anton Zhiyanov

2.Â An Interactive Tour of Go 1.25 â€” Technically, Anton's tour of Go 1.24 was the second most clicked link of the year, but since we're using Go 1.25 right now, this might be more useful to revisit. We look forward to the eventual 1.26Â version!

Anton Zhiyanov

3.Â The â€œ10xâ€ Commandments of Highly Effective Go â€” John adopted a cute theme for what was essentially ten broadly applicable bits of advice for GoÂ developers.

John Arundel

4.Â A No Nonsense Guide to Go Project Layout â€” An article from 2024 that was updated for 2025, where the author told us to say no to overly complicated package structures and shared some tips for preventing â€˜over complicationâ€™ in smallerÂ projects.

Laurent Demailly

5.Â How Go 1.24's Swiss Tables 'Saved Us Hundreds of Gigabytes' â€” A look at how the â€˜Swiss Tablesâ€™ implementation that landed in Go 1.24 helped reduce memory usage in a large in-memory map, how this team's changes were profiled and sized, and the struct-level optimizations that led to even largerÂ savings.

Nayef Ghattas (Datadog)

6.Â [ On | No ] Syntactic Support for Error Handling â€” The topic of how Go handles errors, and if itâ€™s possible to improve the syntax around doing so, has come up many times over the years, but sometimes itâ€™s good to draw a line under things and focus elsewhere. Back in June, Robert explained the issue, some of the proposals made over the years, and the benefits of maintaining the statusÂ quo.

Robert Griesemer

7.Â 15 Go Subtleties You May Not Already Know â€” A roundup of lesser-known Go features or idiosyncrasies thatâ€™s worth a skim, even if only a few jump out at you. Topics include time.After, nil interfaces, and jsonâ€™s - tag.

Harrison Cramer

8.Â Go Concurrency Explorer and Visualizer â€” After watching Rob Pikeâ€™s â–¶ï¸ talk on Go concurrency patterns, a developer created a live WASM-powered coding environment and visualizer to get a better feel for common concurrency patterns. There are several tutorials to enjoy,Â too.

Richard Chukwu

9.Â go tool is One of Go's Best Additions in Years â€” People were excited for this new feature that landed in Go 1.24 that both simplified handling dependencies for dev-time tooling and improved performance by caching runs and reducing dependencyÂ bloat.

Jamie Tanna

10.Â Memory Allocation in Go â€” The efficient allocation and management of memory is a fundamental part of what makes Go programs reliable and responsive. While Go abstracts away most of the complexity, it's worth knowing whatâ€™s going on under theÂ hood.

Nghia Nguyen

ğŸ P.S. We hope you have a great holiday season and we'll be back on Friday,Â JanuaryÂ 9.

ã€

#â€‹582 â€” December 10, 2025

Read the WebÂ Version

ğŸ—“ï¸ A quick note that Go Weekly will be moving to Fridays in January 2026. We still have one more week before the Christmas break, though: we'll be back next Wednesday with our 2025Â roundup!
__
Your editor, Peter Cooper

Go Weekly

Go Proposal: Secret Mode â€” Secret mode, set to land in Go 1.26 behind a flag, lets you run a function where, upon completion, the stack (and registers) will be automatically zeroed to ensure sensitive information doesnâ€™t stay in memory longer than necessary. Ideal for cryptography use cases, the API is simple enough that I expect to see it used moreÂ widely.

Anton Zhiyanov

ğŸ’¡ The full, precise behavior of secret mode and other 'goroutine bubble' features is still being actively discussed,Â however.

Go App: Cloud Infrastructure from Startup to Scale â€” Deploy and scale a real Go app on AWS. Start fast with containers and App Runner, then grow into CI/CD, Terraform, ECS, and production-readyÂ infrastructure.

Frontend Masters sponsor

IN BRIEF:

  • Hajime Hoshi, the creator of the fantastic Ebitengine 2D game engine, reflects on 12 years of building Ebitengine, shares some of the Ebitengine-powered games released in 2025, and lays out some futureÂ developments.

  • Reddit's /r/golang participants discussed their favorite 'don't do this' lessons learned working with Go overÂ time.

  • GoLand 2025.3, the latest version of JetBrains' popular commercial IDE for Go, has been released.

  • ğŸ¤ Russ Cox went on the ACM ByteCast podcast to talk about his background, meeting Go co-designer Rob Pike, as well as the role of Go in the modern developmentÂ landscape.

  • GitHub has improved its Dependabot-based dependency graphs for GoÂ projects.

ğŸ”¥Â This Developer Really Doesn't Like Gin â€” Itâ€™s easy to criticize something, but itâ€™s not so easy to put together several thousand words with numerous diagrams, tables, and examples to back up a rant. Even if you disagree with Efronâ€™s opinion, his treatise on why Gin is â€˜very badâ€™ is.. anÂ experience.

Efron Licht

Compressing Embedded Files in Go â€” If Go wonâ€™t do it, you can just do itÂ yourself.

Vincent Bernat

ğŸ“„ Malicious Go Packages Impersonate Googleâ€™s UUID Library Kirill Boychenko (Socket)

ğŸ“„ Go Optimizations for High Volume Services â€“ Lessons from a Postgres to ElasticsearchÂ pipeline. Julien Singler

ğŸ“„ Go Escape Analysis and Why My Function Return Worked Bonnie Simon

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

RobotGo 1.0: Native Cross-Platform GUI Automation â€” A way to control the pointer, keyboard, read the screen, etc. on macOS, Windows, and Linux (X11). A separate paid version adds Wayland support.

V Caesar et al.

Gremlins: A Mutation Testing Tool for Small Go Modules â€” A different way to put your code, and associated tests, through a stress test with some gremlins mutating your code to see if the tests stand up to scrutiny. Itâ€™s early days, but worth checking out for the logo alone! GitHubÂ repo.

Davide Petilli

Meet Agentic Postgres: The Database Built for AI Agents â€” Spin up Postgres for AI experiments in seconds. Free forever, with forks, vector search, and zeroÂ setup.

Tiger Data sponsor

filesql: SQL Driver for CSV, TSV, XLSX Files, and More â€” Built atop SQLite, filesql provides SQL access to CSV, TSV, LTSV, Parquet, and Excel (XLSX) files fromÂ Go.

CHIKAMATSU Naohiro

Kaiju Engine: A 2D and 3D Game Engine in Go â€” A â€˜work in progressâ€™ project to create a game engine in Go that uses Vulkan behind the scenes. Itâ€™s still early days, however. GitHubÂ repo.

Brent Farris et al.

gorush 1.20: A Push Notification Server, Built on Gin â€” Supports APNS (Apple Push Notification Service), Firebase (FCM), and HMS Push Server (Huawei).

Bo-Yi Wu

  • ğŸ¤– Crush 0.22+ â€“ Charm's Go-powered coding agent tool continues to get even better with v0.22 introducing the ability to search the Web (using DuckDuckGo) and now supporting tools and MCPs that returnÂ images.

  • neo4j-go-driver v6.0 â€“ Official Go driver for working with Neo4j databases using the BoltÂ protocol.

  • GoFr 1.50 â€“ The opinionated microservice development framework adds Azure File StorageÂ support.

  • parquet-go v0.26.0 â€“ Low-footprint library for reading and writing ParquetÂ files.

  • Casbin 3.0 â€“ Open-source access control library for GoÂ projects.

  • Lazygit 0.57 â€“ Simple terminal UI for gitÂ commands.

  • go-github 80.0 â€“ Client library for the GitHub APIÂ v3.

  • Ebitengine 2.9.5 â€“ The 2D gameÂ engine.

  • dskDitto 0.1 â€“ Fast duplicate file finder.

  • fq 0.16 â€“ Like jq for binaryÂ formats.

ğŸ“¢Â  Elsewhere in the ecosystem

Some other interesting stories in the broader landscape:

  • Dolt, a version-controlled relational database built with Go, is now boasting being as fast as MySQL on the Sysbench benchmark.

  • Brian 'Beej' Hall, famous for his various guides for things like network programming and Git, has released Beej's Guide to Learning Computer Science. It's high level and more about the mental models and philosophy of problem solving than any actual coding orÂ math.

  • ğŸ§ Microsoft has launched a VS Code Insiders podcast where the VS Code team gets to go "beyond the release notes" and talk about VS Code's features andÂ ecosystem.

  • Let's Encrypt is celebrating ten years of generatingÂ certificates.

  • Want to try and understand how elliptic curve cryptography works? Here's an attempt at boiling it down.
